Statistics 1: Problem Sheet
  1. 1 Interpretations of Probability
Statistics 1: Problem SheetStatistics 1: Problem Sheet

1 Interpretations of Probability

  1. 1.

    A student is about to play a game against an opponent involving a standard 6-sided dice.

    1. (a)

      She initially assigns the probabilities P⁢(X=x)=16, with x=1,…,6, to each side of the dice. What interpretation of probability might she be using?

    2. (b)

      Her friend urgently tells her before the game starts that the opponent is a cheat; the dice is loaded (i.e. unfair) and rolls a 6 more often than not. She thinks about this information and then assigns new probabilities:

      P⁢(X=6)=0.6andP⁢(X=x)=0.08,for⁢x=1,…⁢5 (1)

      She is still prepared to play the game. What interpretation of probability might she now be using?

    3. (c)

      After playing the game for a while, she diligently notes down the result of every roll of the dice. After 1000 rolls she notes that the number 6 occurred 550 times. She discards her previous assignment and now assigns P⁢(X=6)=0.55 (and assigns the remaining probabilities for x=1,…,5 from the observed counts using the same strategy). What interpretation of probability might she be using here?

    4. (d)

      Were her assignments of probability in parts (a), (b) and (c) correct? Discuss.

    5. (e)

      In part (c), it seems reasonable that she discarded her previous assignment of P⁢(X=6)=0.6 after 1000 rolls. Would it have been reasonable to discard this after 100 rolls, or 10 rolls, or 2 rolls? Discuss (without performing any detailed calculation).

    Much of this course will aim to examine the kind of issues raised in Question 1, to clarify the many ambiguities, and to improve greatly upon the procedures used.

    Solution

    1. (a)

      Well, we should really ask her, but we can see she may just be using the Classical interpretation here, as it is enough. Or, she could be using classical principles within a frequentist or subjectivist interpretation.

    2. (b)

      Now she cannot resort to using a purely a Classical interpretation, as the basic events are not all equally likely, assuming she trusts her friend of course. As she has used some information (incomplete, we note) and provided a set of probabilities she is willing to play the game/gamble with, then this sounds very much like she is operating within a subjective interpretation. However, frequentists aren’t banned from specifying probabilities like this (they may do different things with them though) so this can’t be ruled out either.

    3. (c)

      Now, this sounds very much like a kind of frequency interpretation (classical being ruled out again), as she has directly used the frequency of occurrence of a 6, and discarded her previous (arguably subjective) views. However, note the slight issues: the probability she assigns of P⁢(X=6)=0.55 is highly unlikely to be equal to the “true” limiting frequentist probability p obtained from infinite rolls, and is really just an estimate, albeit a close one. Also, Subjectivists aren’t banned from using data in this way either and can specify probabilities to be anything they want (but they might not discard their initial or “prior” views so readily). So it sounds like more of a Frequentist approach, but if she insists 0.55 is actually “her” probability then it would seem more Subjectivist (remembering that Subjectivists are of course free to employ certain Frequentist or Classical principles). We will spend much of this course developing statistical methods that will clear up all these many ambiguities.

    4. (d)

      What does correct even mean here? Under a Frequentist viewpoint, and imagining the “true” underlying probability exists, then strictly the assignment in part (a) is very wrong, in part (b) it is wrong but closer, and in part (c) it is still wrong but probably closer still. However, under a Subjectivist viewpoint, in part (a) she makes a reasonable specification of equal probabilities given the information she had at the time, so this is acceptable, if one argues she had no initial reason to doubt the character of her opponent. Part (b) again is fine, as she is stating her Subjective assessment given improved information. Part (c) again is fine in isolation (although somewhat naive), although the discarding of her “prior” view from part (b) makes it, in some sense, inconsistent with part (b).

    5. (e)

      Take the cases of 2 or 10 rolls. She would be very unwise to discard her initial assessment and replace it directly with the frequency from the data, as there is still a substantial probability this could be highly misleading e.g. the number of 6’s rolled could be far from the “true” probability. The case of 100 rolls is more borderline and it really depends how much she trusts her prior specification made with her friend’s help in part (b). Again, much of this course will aim to clarify situations like this.
